I rebuilt a Holley carburetor on a 1967 Chrysler New Yorker back in the early eighties. There is a tube that goes through the carb between the two float bowls. I had to make sure that the tube was evenly spaced to allow the float bowels have a balanced pressure vent. Nice to bring back memories! OBTW I put a spacer plate under the carb and it actually gave a snappier response, which is due to increasing air flow mass.

I worked for MCCI ( Metallic Ceramic Coating Inc.) Jet Hot for a summer and I did everything from blasting the old coating, burnishing for Satin Finish, Finishing which was a tub of water and glass beads to get a chrome finish, hanging the parts on racks for the oven and packing. We used the same foam for packing. We would put plastic down and spray the liquid in and it would expand as it cooled. It’s the perfect way to package parts. The only thing I didn’t do was paint. And I’m glad I didn’t paint. They had to be in a heated room we called the barn. Then slide the parts in the oven and bake the coating on at 650 degrees F. It was very hot in the building, usually around 120 - 130 degrees depending on when the oven was opened. I ended up with a kidney stone after I stopped working there. They did coat other things but I worked on the car parts side. The company shut down in the 2000’s as header companies started offering ceramic coated parts to customers. It was an experience. My friends roommate in college from Memphis had a Jet Hot magnet on his fridge. His dad had gotten a header coated while I was working there for his Viper. It was very cool. Thanks for the tour. I learned a lot.

Great video dude.. I love the whole carburetor tangent you got off into.  I have a suggestion for the next video if you want to push the carb series for another video.  What you saw being built was an off-the-shelf bolt on carb for a stock or mildly modified engine.  You should really see what race carb builders do to these stock carbs.  You would be surprised and what is possible using a stock casting.  Dirt track racers run those 4412 500cfm 2 barrels on 600 horsepower engines and make em sing.  You're a math man and love a good spread sheet (as do I), check out the CFM and fuel requirements for 600 horsepower and then think about getting all of that through 1 500cfm 2 barrel carb.  Methanol requires nearly twice as much fuel.  One thing you missed about the stock carb is the power valve.   The power valve radically changes the fuel curve depending on your camshaft dynamics.  You could spend an entire night watching vidoes on power valves.. which one to use for what application, when it's okay to delete them.. so much nerdy gear head fun.  Love the series man. Carburetors are easy to tune and use if you know about them, In most electronic injection systems you have some limited programs on the ECU and that`s it. In some of them you can make your own program and tune but in all of them the correct function of the system depends on various different sensors that you have on the engine and exhaust. But on carburetor you have unlimited tunes that you can tune depends on your immediate inspections with tuning screws or changing parts and because of that we use carburetors yet on our muscle cars.

As a small engine mechanic who works on this bi-daily there are some jets in those carburetors (Specifically your idle jet or aka your pilot jet and air metering orifices) that are so immensely small that even a grain of sand can clog or stuff up one of the jets can cause improper vacuum causing the engine to idle incorrectly.

However, all flaws aside while not being as smart as a computer the only limit of a carburetor is the limit of fluid dynamics and the very laws of physics and aerodynamics itself. It doesn't need a computer to tell it how to work or a circuit board to tell it what to do.

They are like us. They don't use any computers but they know what to do because physics tells it to.

Mr. Shane Weckerly is wrong with "Air Bleed Nozzle" (frame number 11:29 on your video). The brass nozzles he is referring to are "Anti Siphon Nozzles". When you start the engine, air pulled through the ventures of a carburetor cause low pressure which starts pulling gas from the bowl through channels to the carburetor throat, which is a "Siphon". When the engine is turned off, gas will still flow through that siphon until it drains the bowl, so to stop this siphon is an air bleed nozzle, "Anti Siphon Nozzle", not a fuel atomizer, and it has to be exactly the right size. Gas atomizes under the carburetor throttle body in the intake manifold before it enters the combustion chamber... Wow, what a trip down memory lane! I'll bet I still have a Holley or two Benji's dad may have helped build his first year on the job.

I think my first Holley was a good ole 3310 that replaced the stock Carter my 1970 Dodge Dart Swinger 340 came with. Along came the ST-21 Racer Brown cam, 13:1 TRW pistons and head porting, so of course I had to experiment with larger Holley's. I think a Holley 800cfm double pumper (or double "squirters" as they were called during the tour) was next. Funny how I can remember such names and numbers but have no clue what I ate for breakfast yesterday!

About three years later 100 octane leaded gas all but disappeared at the pumps, although it could be bought at the airport for some ridiculous price like .79 cents a gallon, but that's when the 4X4 bug bit and the car got traded for a 73 Power Wagon. I kept the 340 and sold the car with a junkyard 318 transplant.

I swapped the 340 for the stock anemic two barrel 360 for a short while, then moved up to a 68 440 and Torqueflite borrowed from a surplus California Highway Patrol car. Of course the 440 ended up with various modifications and Holley carbs topping it off, and I even experimented with a Six Pac setup off a Cuda (or was it a Challenger?), topped with three Holley 2 barrels.

Holley's were always easy to modify, and believe me, that was needed for off roading! I remember playing with springs to keep the floats from bouncing, and main jet extender tubes were necessary when racing up the steep sand dunes at Glamis. The design must have been very close to perfection back in that era, as the new ones look almost identical. My hat it off to Holley, and thanks for the tour!

Fun fact: My grandfather worked for Holley Carburetor Plant in Paris, Th.  Back in the early 80s they had to vote on their future.  They had to choose between fuel injection or carburetor.  They chose poorly and voted for fuel injection.  Holley didn’t keep the plant open and shut the plant down after my grandfather’s retirement.  That was a huge employer for the small town of Paris, Tn and the loss impacted the town for decades later.

The "slot" @ 26:35 is a fuel dispersal port...That IS the "Transition Circuit" outlet for FUEL not an air signal...The air signal is from the milled channel in the throttle plate base. The small hole below the transition slot is the idle circuit discharge hole that is feed by the idle mixture screws at the sides of the "Metering Block" (Brain) of the carburetor...There is a whole lot of "magic" going on in the metering block...The emulsifying of the air/fuel mixture....Distribution to various circuits and nothing was said about the "Power Valve" which is an intermediate fuel enrichment circuit that is unique to a Holley carburetor. That basic 4 barrel Holley you hold there was designed by a NASCAR mechanic named Ralph Johnson in 1958 and used on NASCAR motors (220MPH motors) until 2011. Holley also is one of the most popular aftermarket Performance Fuel Injection suppliers....Not a fan of them "offshoring" their intake manifold production to the far east...glad Carburetors are still "Home Grown"

See, this is the beauty of a carburetor, and why this "old-fashioned" technology is still around. No voltage. No ECM. No sensors or wiring. Just pure fluid dynamics and vacuum physics. A fully self-regulating mechanical metering system (whence properly adjusted).

I enjoy videos like this but sometimes they lack an overall view. Carburetors are complex because a car’s engine has so many different operating requirements.
They may need seven hundred cfm flow at full throttle or five at idle. The mixture must be proper whether the engine is at a steady speed, or is accelerating or decelerating or is at sea level or at nine thousand feet, or the ambient temperature is 110 degrees or 10. It needs to work on a stock engine that produces a high vacuum signal, or a modified one that produces less.
They have been developed to an amazing degree, but I am happy with fuel injection that doesn’t require me to constantly fiddle with the idle mixture and speed adjustments, or have to change the needles and jets if I move to a different elevation.

For everyone stating FI is simpler... it is and it isn't. To do the same job that a carburetor does, EFI requires:
-high pressure fuel delivery
-pressure regulator (most systems don't read fuel pressure and assume it's constant, so they make it constant)
-air pressure sensors for the manifold and ambient air
-some use a direct measurement flow sensor (MAF) while others calculate from known values
-throttle position sensing, or a servo controlled throttle
-engine and ambient air temperature sensors
-oxygen sensor for closed loop mode (normal driving/cruise, basically)
-voltage sensing to accommodate analog sensors
-RPM sensing (direct or indirect)
-fuel injectors (from one, to many) and high pressure "plumbing" to feed them
-wiring for all of the above
-computer capable of reading all the above and using these inputs to alter a predetermined fuel map quickly enough to be responsive, and containing hardy enough transistors to control the injectors by pulsing them (PWM)

All of that is reasonably accomplished by a part less than a cubic foot in size that operates with low pressure fuel delivery (since it has it's own accumulator, the bowl) and only two control inputs, throttle and whatever mechanism is used to control the choke if not automatic. At it's simplest it literally needs a fuel line and a throttle cable connection, and a single tuning session... and just works afterwards. Not perfectly, but within a few percent in the vast majority of conditions. It's modern economy standards and emission controls that drive the need for 'perfection' beyond what a carburetor can manage, but not every situation calls for that, especially in the motorsports world.

More complicated Holley carbs have "vacuum secondaries", which open the second set of bores "as needed", based upon airflow. That is Holley's main claim to fame. Often the secondary bores are much larger than the primaries (termed "spread-bore"), which gives more efficiency in normal driving where the smaller primary bores are used. The one shown has the same size primaries and secondaries (termed "square-bore"). It also has "mechanical secondaries", meaning they open via the pedal. It is closer to the original Carter Aluminum Four-Barrel (AFB) of the 1960's, whose descendant is today's Edelbrock used by many classic owners for lower cost and simplicity. Others of note are the Carter Thermoquad (many Mopars) and Rochester Quadrajet (many GM), which were the last-gasp designs before the electronic feedback carbs of the early 1980's. Both had secondaries which open via air-flow ("as needed"), unless you floored-it to force them open which could bog down the engine. Both were spread-bore with tiny primaries, so gave better mileage in normal driving.

Some fuel injections systems had similar ideas to the carburetor. Throttle Body Injection (TBI) had a similar single throttle body, but a high pressure pump delivered fuel, for a finer spray, and electronics calculated and controlled the required fuel rather than venturi effects. One interesting system was the Bosch L-Jetronic (1981-91 on many Euro cars) which had an "air plate" similar to Thermoquad and Quadrajet, but controlled fuel flow from a high-pressure pump, feeding a mechanical fuel distributor to a spray nozzle at each cylinder.

Lol the choke doesn’t think for the carb. It lets the engine run on cold warm or hot days. The spring coil tightens as it cools and expands as it heats up in turn it opens the front flaps to draw in more air, that’s why the older carbureted vehicles u would here the old expression “my car is cold natured” lol no it’s not!, the choke isn’t adjusted properly or the coil in the choke is bad. And the cars prior to the early 80’s didn’t have a electric chokes they relied on the engine heat from the exhaust port on the intake to heat the coil in the choke

Overproduction makes me as nervous as overpopulation. We live in a country that allows these things to consistently happen without a resolution being purposed and tested, before the negative affects of these things happening, that will cause irreversible damage. (Like radium pills)
If we the people, that make up this country and planet, don't make plans for a difference now, to alleviate the extensive damage done; we will be paying the consequences a lot longer than reaping the benefits, even more so than we do today (which is a scary thought).
A lot of people know this yet, things still stay relatively the same, and in some cases worse; like the overproduction of lithium.
This has caused massive electronic waste piles destroying our landfills, many properties around them, and surrounding towns. For example, overproduction leads people to believe they are getting great deals ordering from Chinese websites, to save 2$ on your next game controller; when in reality, all the old controllers, and new ones that don't sell, are thrown away so easily. This all leads to overly-polluted areas, once again, in our country the US of A, as well as many other counties, including your own reading this now.
China used to have the #1 most polluted water ways in the world but now just falls short of India. Electronic waste is one of the #1 reasons for largely polluted areas, as well as, farm run-off, and toxic waste dumped by all of our governments, and their contractors.

I've been a car guy since the 70s. I immediately identified your 830 C.F.M. double pumper. Your demo carb had no choke (and milled off choke housing), two accelerator pumps (hence the term "double pumper"), mechanical secondary barrels (as opposed to vacuum secondaries), two metering blocks (some have metering plates on the secondaries) and appears to have  1 13/16" diameter throttle bores. This very similar to NASCAR carburetors, before they switched to fuel injection about 10 years ago. Also of note: a large number of parts on the Holley four barrels are available in different sizes/capacities for tunability; such as main jets, squirter sizes, accelerator pump capacities, vacuum actuation points of power valves, etc. And you thought building them was magical.
Kinda sad to think that this place probably won't exist in 50 years at this capacity... I hope they are able to transition to the new world of cars.

You want to see an engineering masterpiece look up an old Rochester carburetor.  It is like an automatic transmission valve body.  Or even a Edelbrock

Your "simplified" carb is a lawnmower carb, so it is real, just basic.  You haven't even touched on CV carbs, round slide/flatslide carbs.  And then you have the "jetless" carbs like lectron.  Most have an idlejet and mainjet, then the transition is done with the needle in the slide.  Some have accelerator pumps, some have a midrange jet, and CV work similar but the throttle isn't connected to the slide.

When I was learning to fly I was surprised to learn a lot of General Aviation planes (like a Cessna) still primarily use carburetors on their engines. I think overall the reason is it boils down to cost and ease of maintenance. Also there is additional operational complexity that both carb or fuel injector systems need to cater for. In most General Aviation planes you will have a "carb heat" leaver that you pull when putting the engine to low power and descending, this makes the air flowing into the carburetor warm (from the engine heat) and the carburetor doesn't ice up. I guess a fuel injector system is more complicated as it has to automate all of this.
Anyhow, I guess my point here is there are still good and valid reasons carburetors are used, and it's not simply old and outdated tech for muscle cars.

I'm surprised that they made you blur the QA station.  It's not like the competition doesn't know about them, and can't make their own.   I'm sure at some point, they've even hired ex Holley employees who knew the process, to share it with them.   They're not supposed to, but it happens.

But why are carbs still being made? What new engines would still use carbs rather than fuel injection? Ok, the end of the video explained that they are for existing carbed cars. But do any modern large engines (ie not lawn mowers) still use carbs?

Not to be confrontational ... small engines, like lawnmowers and portable generators, use carburetors closer to the simple carb that you made. They do more of it with cast or drilled internal passages.

Automobile carburetors, especially Holley carbs, have more intricacies. They need to idle smooth, drive, and put a ton of fuel out when you stand on it. They have to be able to perform well, regardless if they're cold or hot. Freezing mornings, to hard driving through a hot desert at noon. And the Holly has redundancies.

I've been working on cars roughly forever. I started working on small engines too a couple decades ago. Sometimes, when you're diagnosing a weird problem, it's good to be able to trace through everything to find the problem. Sometimes, it'll be some corrosion in one passage, that could be missed by just spraying it with carb cleaner and changing the gaskets and o-rings. It is really neat to see the manufacturing process for things I've been working on forever.

Ever thought of making a film investigating zero point energy? If that's not possible how about different building mortar strengths and why some mixes are better than others.

Unlike cement and gypsum plaster (which have about a 4 month shelf life), lime putty has no shelf life so long as it's sealed off from contact with air it won't set and is better the older it gets. However because it takes years to fully carbonate industry prefers the faster setting cement but annually the global cement concrete output is about 4 billion tons and 1 ton of cement produces 3/4 of a ton of carbon dioxide which is too costly for the health of our planet.

It's been recently discovered that when Roman cement (it's actually lime) was submerged in sea water, after a number of years this produces a mineral called Phillipsite which bends rather than shatters when a structure is under stress. Roman harbour sea walls are stronger today than when they were first built.

In actual fact the older matured lime makes the mortar/plaster much stickier. I even heard of some 500 year old Italian lime pits discovered during new building work and the lime putty was still usable.

I do historical repair work using lime putty mortars and plasters which I slake (pronounced slack) and make into a basic lime mortar which I use on my plastering jobs.

My last job was to fixing a water damaged, 15th century, 24 wooden lath panelled ceiling with haired mortar & a top 3ml plaster skim coat.

For a future demo I have a buckets worth of old snail shells that I've collected over the last 5 years and have enough to make a calcium carbonate (lime) mortar from them, would you like to go on a business jolly to England (US citizens have no quarantine time unlike British citizens going to the States) to come and make a film on the subject plus the snail shell demo?

Your carburetor was a real carburetor! In fact a lot of the early carbs were even more simple. Some had a reservoir of gas that would run back down into the fuel tank, so no float was needed. Definitely a lot more going on with a carburetor for a variable speed engine than one for a governed fixed-speed engine. The simple clear mock-up carburetor is a lot closer to what's already on a lawnmower because all the enrichment and dynamic metering isn't needed on an engine expected to run at a set RPM. Now cars go all over the place from idle to full power with varying power demand, etc., so the complexity to handle all that really shows a difference when the same task is done for a vehicle application.

Holley is one of the most famous manufacturers of carburetors. What some don't realize is that they also make throttle body fuel injectors. The product looks very similar to the four barrel carb, but without all of the computing and metering stuff. Instead, it has a digital computer.

Carbs can also make more power on the same engine versus EFI, due to the cooling effect the atomisation of the fuel has on the intake charge. Cooler air contains more oxygen for the same volume which means you can burn more fuel which means more power. The main advantage of EFI is the high tune-ability and data gathering via the computer that controls it all.

Great video. If you're looking for more automotive type ideas, might be worth looking into Regulated 2 Stage (R2S) turbo systems. It's a small turbo/big turbo setup on engines to negate the drawbacks of a single large or single small turbo, giving the best of both worlds. Great response and wide powerband. They differ from compound or sequential turbos in that they kinda operate as both systems during different ranges of the RPM band/load states. All this controlled by various change over valves etc managed by the ECU. We've got two diesels using this system, both BMW M57's. Probably one of the few applications of this stateside. There's a good number of engines using similar systems across the pond though. Just another interesting and kinda unique system.

I enjoy your channel, but sometimes have mixed feelings when watching the videos, especially the rocket videos. I decided to become an engineer in the third grade after NASA came to visit my class to talk about the shuttle. In the fourth grade I excelled and tested five grades ahead of my peers. Unfortunately, that caught the attention of the creators of a new self-guided, unstructured teaching style that in the fifth grade completely derailed the only structure I had in my life - school. Because I performed so poorly in that class, from that grade on nearly every teacher and counselor treated me as if I were stupid, and some openly called me stupid and an idiot, saying my IQ test had to be wrong.
With no one in my life to contradict all the people telling me I was stupid I came to believe it myself, and gave up.
Eventually, I realized they were wrong but the damage was done and it was far too late in life to pursue becoming an engineer.
Consider yourself fortunate to have a father who encouraged you. It might be cliche, but how adults treat the children in their care will affect that child's entire life.

26:10 1) Carbs actually atomize fuel better than the typical FI systems we have available. Maybe formula 1 cars have better injectors but at the price points for consumer vehicles, FI is objectively worse than a properly tuned carb. That said, the FI system adapts to the environment better which is why most new cars are FI. But for any older project car or existing carb vehicle, it's cost prohibitive to retrofit an FI setup and it exorbitantly increases the difficulty in tuning it. With a carb you can do tuning with just a screwdriver and a couple of wrenches.

A weber DCOE is a very sophisticated carb.........the smarts they have in their emulsion tubes are very cool, the Holley we see here has the metering block to do the same thing.   Although all carbs have similar principles and components, they vary enormously on application  the mechanical means those things are achieved.   Carbs can have performance issues if there is any gunk or foreign material coating a part or clogging a passageway which is why ethanol/gasoline blends are trouble and they periodically need to be disassembled and cleaned for best results.   They can still deliver performance close to EFI but have simple reliability once they are correctly set for an application.   In WW2 carburetors in Spitfire and Mustang went up against the mechanical fuel injection German engines and the two systems according to Stanley Hooker at RR were a dead heat in effectiveness in supercharged engines.  Specifically because the Merlin engine had superchargers that sucked the fuel/air out of the carburetor and mixed them completely and fully evaporated the gasoline so it was delivered to each cylinder as a vapor/air mixture that combusted efficiently.  Once they solved the negative g-force problem, the carburetor equipped Merlin could not be faulted.

If you want to look at fuel injection, take a look at Saab 900 Classics. Not just because they are great cars, but also because they both had the mechanical injection (on the 8V models) and electronic injection (16V models). And because the engine is mounted the way it is (under a 45º angle lengthwise, like a rear-wheel drive car with half of a V8 engine) you can see all of the parts that make up the fuel injection portion quite easily. Also gives you a good look at the ignition system on stock cars with distributors and tuned cars with the Trionic electronic ignition system (an early version of what all gasoline cars use today). AND it allows you to explain the differences between port injection (on the 900s) and the later direct injection (on other cars).

I'm a technician with over 25 years experience. I came into this industry about 15 years after Electronic Fuel Injection started to take off.

I learned how to tune a carb engine in College at Wallace State. We actually got my 1971 Ford F100 300ci 6 to achieve about 28mpgs with a 3 speed. I was impressed by Fred Shockley's knowledge.

I can tell you why Fuel Injection took over.

Laziness. People didn't want to pay to tune up their cars. And Emissions standards. Those 2 reasons killed the carb on your mass produced vehicles.

I'd also like to add why I prefer Fuel injection over traditional carb on my "racecars" ....

Once a carb is set, and the distributor is locked down, that's basically what you have. The AF ratio and timing curve is basically set.

With Fuel Injection I can adjust timing and AF ratios pretty much infinitely, and by RPM.

This is why we have a flatter HP/TQ curve on today's performance engines. And.... now we have VVT so we can also sweep the cam to a degree to achieve maximum performance from an engine. Think "VTEC" from Honda. All modern V8 engines have these benefits.

Carbs are cool, and they can make great power numbers, but Fuel Injection allows us to have more power "under the curve" across the RPM usable range, with better reliability, and cleaner Emissions.

That "squirt" nozzle that's part of the accelerator pump or transition circuit: it's there because when you crack the throttle open, whatever intake manifold vacuum you had is immediately lost so there's nothing left to draw fuel from the venturi. Most automotive engines normally have around 18" of vacuum at idle, as the throttle is only slightly open, causing an air restriction. it immediately drops to about 5" inches under normal acceleration or cruise, and almost zero under hard accel. If a carb didn't have an accelerator pump (some also have a "power valve" for additional boost), the engine would suddenly lean out, backfire, and probably die as soon as the throttle was opened.

And not to be nitpicky but technically you're not adjusting the needle in relationship to the float. That relationship stays constant, as the float just keeps the needle pushed into its seat, thereby closing off the fuel inlet. On a Holley, you're moving the entire needle/seat assembly upward or downward to adjust fuel level. (And the higher the level, the richer the engine runs, but it's a relatively slight change compared to re-jetting or adjusting mixture screws.)

So Dad has a mfg background, I see.  The transfer slot is not letting air into the metering block but letting out emulsified fuel from the idle circuit before it gets to the idle needle.  Kind of like an on demand bypass. As the throttle blade opens the manifold vacuum works on a larger surface area of the slot and thus draws more fuel.  All the air that goes into the metering block goes in thru the various air bleeds in the top of the carb body.  One set for idle and one for main circuit per block.

It is not that you were wrong, You had a very simple carby, for a  small ( 100 cc ? ) engine that when running is set to run at a near constant speed. They are comparing it to a high performance carby for a large ( 4,5,6 or more liter ) engine that can go from idle to full power and back again often. (eg idling at the lights, flat to the floor on green, whoops there is a cop over there ). The only thing wrong on yours was an adjustment for fuel mixture. You should have a look at the carby of a RC engine. A "not controlled" engine on a control line plane makes yours look complicated. Fuel tank at a level, sometimes pressurised, a simple venturi with a needle valve to set the mixture. The throttle part is what makes it complicated in that the throttle needs to change the settings on how much fuel can flow.

I had my first experience with carburetors around 27 years ago in high school. Took an auto shop class and needed to rebuild the carb on my truck. Had no idea what I was doing. Bought the rebuild kit, pulled the truck into the shop, pulled the carb and took it to the teacher. He then proceeded to tear it down, throw stuff in the trash, make jokes, and then put it all back together. All while explaining nothing. Fast forward to 2019 and I took some automotive classes at my local community college. When we got to fuel systems, it was all fuel injection. The only mention of carbs was the prof saying they are old and we’ll probably never see one in a shop. Why? Because they were teaching us to be techs at dealerships. Now it’s 2021, I work for one of the largest aftermarket parts retailers in the world and sell these Holley’s on a weekly basis. I just learned more from this 30 min video than I did in high school or my auto classes in college…

This is why you dont leave gas in an unused engine long term. The gas evaporates and leaves a crusty residue which clogs all those tiny passages and jets. It is a nightmare to get clean sometimes, and a carb won't work correctly with even a surprisingly small amount of gunk in one of those passages.

Back in the 80's I worked as a Technical Illustrator for Borg-Warner and was responsible for drawing the exploded and detail views of new model carburetors which were used to create instruction sheets for carburetor rebuild kits... You dad knows what those are!!! The engineers used to take the new carburetors apart, put all the pieces in a shoe box, then put it on my shelf to illustrate (pen, ink, ellipse templates). Seeing all those carb parts brought back memories.

Takeaways...
1. I love how fascinated you were with the automatic choke!
2. This was great in that you were able to compare your homemade carburetor with a traditional manufactured carb.
3. Manufacturing videos: If you inspired at least one person to create, build, or design something... fantastic!

Also, if you ever decide to keep expanding on the carburetors, I remember illustrating one of the first EFI (electronic fuel injection) setups. They basically took the traditional carburetor throttle body and mounted an electronic fuel injector in the opening... woolah. Times have changed.

26:23 "...you can fix them anywhere." <-- Truth! Back in the late 70s I was flying down a South Alabama back country road in my Holley equipped Mustang. I came to a cross-road and had to stop. Unfortunately, the engine stopped too - right in the middle of Nowhere, Alabama on a Sunday afternoon. Nothing open, no stores in sight anyway and no cell phones back then. I took the Holley off and found that the float pivot rod had backed out of the bowl housing which allowed the float to fall away and flood the carb. I crimped the end of the rod with some ViseGrips, tapped it back in, reassembled and reinstalled the carb and took off. Never had another problem! 😄

My brother, the long time mechanic had this story: back in the day when they introduced one of the complex 4-barrel carburetors (Rochester Quadrajet, I think) he attended an introductory seminar given by the manufacturer. At the end of the seminar, the question was raised about rebuilding them. The company rep said "oh no, these are far too complex, they have to be rebuilt by the factory". Within a year, rebuild kits became available and mechanics across the nation were rebuilding them. That speaks to human ingenuity.

These days, better mechanics have become electronic technicians, understanding and analyzing digital data communication and sensor signals with sophisticated instrumentation such as oscilloscopes. Again speaking to human ingenuity.

The foam machine is called a "foam-in-place". It combines polyol resin and isocyanate in to a bag (pumped from 55 gal drums or 250 gal ibc containers). The machine is really cool. You can tell it how big the bag/liner needs to be and how full you want the volume of the bag to be filled with foam once fully expanded. Pretty neat machine.

Sorry, Destin... BUT having worked on both carburetors (including the 95 Savage 650 SL that I currently ride) AND fuel injection, from 93 Ford's to the big block Detroit Diesels... I have to point out that... no... In point of fact, fuel injection is NOT so complicated at all... It can be done as simply as an electric "whir" pump to keep fuel pressure up, and a "pick up" in a distributor to "squirt" action the fuel into the cylinder and fire just about any timing difference you want... ALL of it, based on "Top Dead Center" for the firing piston in question... It's dubious and sophisticated... but not difficult...

We've advanced to "fire control modules" and "coil packs"... BUT the actual mixing and burning of fuel isn't so much more intensive than a carburetor ever was...

AND for those who insist that their "technology" is so advanced and so much better, no... It's not. You get the laws of chemistry and physics, and a carb' works the way it works because those laws CAN NOT BE VIOLATED... It's just tunable and adjustable with a screwdriver rather than pissing away tens of thousands of dollars on a complicated computer to do the tuning... that's it. ;o)

Obsolete technology.

Compared to severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) in 2003, the novel coronavirus that broke out in China last year has spread faster and wider, affecting more than 50 countries in just two months. There have also been cases in which the incubation period extends beyond 14 days and the infected patients show no symptoms, making it harder to stem the virus' spread.

Another challenge is the lack of preventive vaccines or therapeutic drugs. Although a number of companies are working or planning to work on it, the outcome remains uncertain. Remdesivir, a new drug made by Gilead Sciences, for example, is expected to work only on mild or moderate cases. The lengthy drug approval process may also mean that even before a drug is put on the market, the quick spread and mutation of the virus may have made it beyond treatment.

Some hope that the epidemic would fade like SARS as the temperature rises, but there is no evidence yet. “We absolutely don’t know that,” says Trudie Lang at the University of Oxford. “I keep asking virologist colleagues this and nobody knows.”

Millions of people are placed under quarantine as the Chinese communist regime scrambles to contain the virus. With no end of quarantine in sight, many, especially those in Wuhan, feel trapped in their own homes, and their mental health is worrisome, which may lead to another humanitarian crisis.

As China's leaders grapple with the epidemic and its devastating impact on the economy and people's physical and psychological well-being, I am writing this open letter to share my understanding of the plague. I hope that they will learn from history and find a solution that addresses the fundamental, underlying causes of the epidemic.

Plagues in Ancient Times
A lot can be learned from plagues in the ancient times, whether in China or in the West. During the Ming Dynasty, for example, a plague broke out in 1580 and infected more than half of the families in Datong (in today’s Shanxi Province), and it later spread to Beijing as well as southern China. When it broke out again in Shanxi Province in 1633, many people fled and some families had no survivors. Another surge of the plague in 1641, three years before the dynasty’s end, wiped out a significant portion of the population in China.

Besides plagues, the Ming Dynasty also faced other threats, such as the rebelling forces from Li Zicheng (also known as the Dashing King). The plagues, though, seemed to infect only the Ming Dynasty’s troops, not soldiers of Li Zicheng or the invading Manchus. Moreover, after infecting China for decades and weakening the Ming forces, the plague diminished in 1644 after the Manchu established the Qing Dynasty. To some extent, this plague seemed to be a catalyst for the transition of dynasties.

In the West, the plagues in the Roman Empire were also well known in history. After Nero began to persecute Christians, several major plagues took place: the Autumn Plague in 65 AD, the Antonine Plague (165-180), the Plague of Cyprian (250-270), and the Plague of Justinian (541-542).

During the Antonine Plague, for example, there were up to 2,000 deaths a day in Rome. With a mortality rate of about 25%, the total deaths were estimated at five million. The disease killed as much as one-third of the population in some areas and weakened the Roman army, ending a relatively peaceful period of Roman history.

The plagues stopped miraculously after people awakened in 680 and began to reflect on the cruelty against Christians as well as the general moral decay of society. In 680, Roman citizens carried the bones of Saint Sebastian (256-288, killed during the persecution by Diocletian) and processed through the streets. As people repented of their wrongdoings, the plague miraculously vanished in Rome.

People in other areas of the empire heard about this and followed their example, asking for the bones of Saint Sebastian to offer repentance. When a plague broke out in Venice in 1575, about 50,000 people died. Similarly, a plague occurred in Lisbon in 1599. In both cases, people marched with the bones of holy people in repentance, and the plagues ended.

Origin of the Coronavirus Outbreak
So how did the coronavirus epidemic start in Wuhan? One theory pointed to a seafood market in Wuhan, but the first documented COVID-19 cases had never been to the seafood market. Attention was soon turned to China’s only Biosafety Level 4 microbiology lab in the Wuhan Institute of Virology, known as the National Biosafety Laboratory and equipped to handle deadly coronaviruses, Ebola, and other pathogens.

The New York Post published an article on February 22, 2020, warning its readers, “Don’t buy China’s story: The coronavirus may have leaked from a lab.” The article noted, “the People’s Liberation Army’s top expert in biological warfare, a Maj. Gen. Chen Wei, was dispatched to Wuhan at the end of January to help with the effort to contain the outbreak.” Chen is an expert who has studied SARS, Ebola, and anthrax. The report pointed out, “This would not be her [Chen's] first trip to the Wuhan Institute of Virology either, since it is one of only two bioweapons research labs in all of China.”

Whatever the theories are, the outcome of the epidemic is disastrous to China. So many people are dying, and the economy is suffering badly.

While people are venting their distrust in the government and calling for a change of the system, I believe there is a deeper reason for everything.

History Has the Answer
Much like the plagues in ancient Rome that occurred after Nero began to persecute Christians, I believe that the fundamental reason for the coronavirus outbreak is the Chinese communist regime's persecution of Falun Gong practitioners.

Falun Gong, a meditation system based on the principles of Truthfulness-Compassion-Forbearance, has enabled millions of its practitioners to improve both health and character since its introduction to the public in 1992. Its main teachings, Zhuan Falun, has been translated into 40 languages, and people in more than 100 countries practice the spiritual discipline.

As more and more people were drawn to Falun Gong, Jiang Zemin launched a nationwide campaign against the practice in July 1999. The scale and severity of the persecution are unprecedented.

In the past 20 years, numerous practitioners have been arrested, detained, imprisoned, tortured, or even had their organs harvested. More than 4,300 are confirmed to have died as a result of the persecution. Due to the communist regime's information blockade, the actual death toll is likely to be much higher.

Jiang’s policy of “defaming their [Falun gong practitioners’] reputation, bankrupting them financially, and destroying them physically” is no less severe than what Nero did to Christians.

One plague after another struck Rome after the persecution of Christians began. If history is any indication, could the current coronavirus outbreak be a hint from heaven to warn against the persecution of Falun Gong practitioners, which has entered its 21st year in 2020?

Now do fuel injectors.

Fuel Injection is not more complex than carburetion. Fuel injection is simple:
There are two states of fuel injection, Open Loop, and Closed Loop.
In Open Loop, a default amount of fuel in sprayed into the engine for an assumed amount of oxygen until the sensors are ready to work.
In Closed Loop, Airflow in is measured, and fuel is sprayed in to achieve the desired mixture. On the exhaust side, the combustion gasses are measured to make sure the mixture result was correct, and if not, the mixture is adjusted for the next cycle.
Super simple.
A carburetor on the other hand is all about using tricks, linkages, diaphragms, flow rates, pressures and whatnot that all need to be perfect or it doesn't work. We just saw all the parts and steps. It's stupendously complex.
With fuel injection, you have 3 components: An airflow meter, and injector, and an oxygen sensor in the exhaust.
If any of the 3 components fall out of spec, your fuel injection computer compensates, up to 20-30 percent, before you start having issues.
You can't do that with a carburetor.

Deeper dive down the rabbit hole... Surface finish after the carb., rough or smooth? Some testing has "shown" that rough surface finish (CNC or golf ball dimple) can help the air/fuel mixture stay atomized better by preventing surface wetting. This can help to provide more horsepower for a given setting (or jet size). I can link to my research that gives a couple more links, that will inevitably lead you to even more searching and hopefully end up with you actually finding a concrete answer. For a lot of people, this is pure voodoo, but for others it is competitive fact that they apply to everything they race. I wished you would have talked a little more about the air bleeds and the air/fuel emulsification. Remember in your last video when the fuel droplets would squirt out just after the intake stroke and just hang in the air waiting for the next intake stroke? That's because the fuel has momentum and that fuel coming out after the intake stroke is actually bad. Ideally you only want fuel flow when the engine is sucking, or "signalling" as they the experts would say, the carb. They emulsify the fuel with air to make it lighter and allow it to change direction (flowing/not-flowing) much faster in the booster. That blew my mind when I learned about that.

Carburetors are fascinating. I was mystified by them before a mechanic coworker showed me the basic idea. I asked him how one works, and he said "go get me a soda can, put some water in it, a drinking straw, and the air hose." After a good spray I understood, lol.  But there's one reason to be wary of them in the modern world - ethanol fuel. Since they store fuel at atmospheric pressure, sitting around for any length of time can let the more volatile elements evaporate and leave the additives behind to clog jets and passages. Fuel stabilizer helps, but it's a constant concern for anything you don't drive and refill frequently. The smaller the engine the bigger problem it is. Fuel injectors and pumps keep the gas under pressure which prevents it from evaporating, but the ethanol can cause other problems too. Why we put this stuff in gasoline is just insane, it's so bad for the vehicle.

Awesome Destin, this is the great follow up all of us carb people messaged you about!  Another suggestion:  Explore how the carb transitions between circuits.  You would love the fluid dynamics part.  For example, the accelerator pump:  The reason you need that is because when the butterfly valve (throttle) is closed, you have a fair bit of vacuum drawing fuel through the carb into the engine, but when you step on it, the valve opens and your vacuum momentarily goes to zero, right when you need more fuel.  The accelerator pump takes care of that by squirting fuel directly into the engine.  Without it, you couldn't go to full throttle without a huge stumble.   Side note:  this is why people pump the throttle before starting.  The fuel in the accelerator pump is squirted into the engine which acts like a primer which also squirts fuel in for the starting phase.

EFI modification systems can no longer be used on a DOT certified vehicle, which means the entire hotrod industry will end because it has become a crime. Your best video EVER! For personal reasons Destin this made cry and smile. As I said on Twitter my dad used to work for Holley for all of my childhood. My dad passed away in Jan 2020, and this brought back memories from when my dad and me got a private tour of this same factory back in ‘94 or ‘96. My dad worked in Paris, TN and they shut our plant down in the ‘80s. Sadly Holley didn’t have enough jobs to transfer everyone so my dad stayed in Paris and ran a local business for years putting me through college. Years took a toll on my dad and became disabled. Thinking back, I would say the Holley plant tour we made while I was still in college at MSU may have been the last long walk my dad and I ever took together. The interaction between you and you dad in this video made me smile so much.

Really cool to see that manufacturnig facility, and especially cool that they manage to do quite a bit of the work in-house, in the US. The only unfortunate part was that they were building carburetors... which, in all honesty, I cannot imagine should be selling in the quantities that that facility indicates... despite the amount of engineering that's gone into these modern ones, I have serious doubt they they'll ever come close to the efficiency, flexibility in operating ranges (such as fuel composition, ambient environment, load, etc), and yes... even diagnosability (no, computers aren't hard to work on - you just need to program the computer to test and communicate relevant data, and the right other computer to plug into it and read that!)

One area where I think analog fuel metering does actually work surprisingly well is in diesel engines - I suspect mostly because there's no need to meter the fuel based on measured airflow or air-massm since diesels are happy to run extremely lean (and as I understand, part of why their thermal efficiency and thus fuel efficiency is so much better than gassers!). Injection pumps have always fascinated me immensely more than the cabujators on silly old asthmatic gas-jobs, and I know that because of the insane pressure needed to atomize diesel fuel, the injection pumps are manufatured with tolerances that would make everyone at Holley weep softly. I'd love to see you look at the internals of a diesel injection pump and show how they work and even talk a little about the differences between the engine types - compression ignition vs spark and why the injection pump timing is so important etc (inline style always looked the coolest to me, but I know there are some really wild designs out there!)

Alright now THAT is a factory tour! I love how little they felt needed to be 'obscured' from the camera. Every component and step of the process is incredibly visual and goes to show the technical brilliance in what is a very 'traditional' mechanical component. Newer computerized, fuel-injection tech is a technical marvel, but the relative simplicity of an old-fashioned carburetor is something that is great to grow up seeing.

I started driving in a 70's model Toyota, despite it being 20 years my senior. It may have been a fickle beast that had it's moods and ups-and-downs. But it was carburetted, and that component was a key part of the engine that I became incredibly familiar with in keeping that car on the road. Rebuilt the carb as a teenager and going hands-on with virtually all the same components shown in this video of a modern-designed one really was a treat. Something you can learn a lot from just tinkering with it. All the smaller pieces performing a precise ballet to work in sync and let specific amounts of fuel and air into the engine based on the engine's need and response to the driver input (throttle).

Most notable difference between that older model and this modern equivalent I can spot was in the automatic choke. The one on that Toyota was a much simpler style that, still using a coiled bi-metalic spring, flowed heated water (Coolant) from the radiator system to 'sense' the Engine operating temperature and open the choke slowly as the engine warmed up. Seeing that same task performed electronically now is pretty interesting all on it's own!

12:08 I don't mean to be a negative Nancy, but the automatic choke is actually one of the biggest deficits of carburetion vs. fuel injection. An electrically-heated bimetallic strip slowly closing the choke essentially functions as a simple timer influenced by ambient temperature. It lacks the ability to compensate for further complicating factors like throttle position, engine load state, and so forth. This is where fuel injection using oxygen sensors for feedback shines.

Consider that in a car's duty cycle, warm up happens almost every time the engine is started. Short trips and cold weather can mean that a car spends more time in warm up than at a nominal 210F oil temperature. The imprecision of the choke hampers the carburetor's ability to maintain the correct stoichiometric ratio during this phase, no matter how carefully the air and fuel metering are machined.

This imprecision is largely responsible for the stink of a carbureted vehicle's exhaust the first few miles it drives. We've all been at a stoplight behind an old truck running so rich that you could smell the hydrocarbons spewing from the exhaust. Now, there are other culprits such as spark quality and advance, poor valve and piston ring sealing from an aging engine, etc. that can aggravate this condition, but faulty mixture is the original sin. If everyone still drove carbureted vehicles with our expanding population, catalytic converters would last a few years max, and the air in places like LA, Phoenix, SLC would be so noxious as to be basically unfit for respiration.

In 1997, I inherited my great grandfathers '76 Chevy Caprice Classic as my first car that I drove all through high school and beyond. The first thing my dad and I did to that car was to put that same four barrel Holley carb on its 350 small block V8. Man I loved that car. It had 48,000 original miles. My great grandad was probably in his 70s when he bought it brand new in 76 and it just sat in his car port, not being driven most of the time. He passed and the car sat at my grandfather's through most of the 80s under a cover and a tent. He passed in 97, my dad and I went to clean out his house, my dad handed me the keys to the Chevy and said, "Happy birthday, son." It wasn't even my birthday for another 5 months. lol. I drove it home from my granddad's at age 15 in 197 and I felt like king of the world in that gigantic car. It earned the nickname The Tank from my friends in high school because we joked one night that if I ever got in a wreck, I'd be fine. It would be like a tank hitting a tricycle. My family called it the boat or the yacht because when you drove it down the highway it kind of floated over the road. It felt like riding over water in a big boat. The fuel gauge never worked. The AC never worked and I live in a Florida. And in an era when all my friends were putting CD players in their cars, I was stuck with an 8 track player. lol. I miss that car. I sold it to pay for moving expenses to college in 2000. I regret that every time I think about it. I'm rambling. Just seeing that carburetor brought back a lot of memories.

Fuel injection is like an exploded carburetor. All the crucial functions still exist, but over a greater span. You have a metering device for airflow and for fuel (Mass airflow and fuel injectors). But, unlike carburetors, fuel injection is more flexible across the range and even compensates for altitude. Carburetors on V8 engines are designed for ranges of airflow, from 500 to 1000CFM, and you buy the size that fits your engine. Fuel injection can be tweaked by software and injector sizes, without much need to swap out other parts of the system. Plus, turbochargers work easier with EFI than with carbs. The biggest reason we have fuel injection is for efficiency. And, unlike a carb, the fuel system can momentarily shut off when fuel is not necessary, like coasting downhill or to a stop. It also precisely regulates the air/fuel ratio many times per second to maintain the optimal ratio per demand, without wasting excess fuel. Carbs are fine for hot rods, but fuel injection is better for the environment. A carburetor cannot compensate for a dirty air filter or climbing a 6,000ft mountain. But, like your tour guide said, they're simple to fix on the side of the road and parts are cheap and readily available at any part store. Keep up the great videos Destin!

I don't know what to say so here is a waffle recipe:

INGREDIENTS

1¾ cups all-purpose flour
2 tsp baking powder
½ tsp salt
1 Tbsp granulated sugar
3 eggs
1¾ cups whole milk
½ cup vegetable oil
½ tsp pure vanilla extract (optional)

Prep Time: 15 minutes
Cook Time: 30 minutes

Total Time: 45 minutes
Yield: Makes 4 to 5 waffles

PREPARATION

Pre-heat your waffle iron to its hottest setting. Placing a cookie-sheet under it can help catch any batter drippage during cooking.
Pre-heat oven to 200°F.
Sift together flour, baking powder and salt.
Beat eggs thoroughly. Whisk in sugar, milk and oil.
Add liquid ingredients to dry ingredients and mix gently until combined. Don't overmix!
Spray both surfaces of your waffle iron with cooking spray.
Ladle 4 to 6 oz (½ to ¾ cup) batter on the iron and close it. It's not unusual for a bit of batter to seep out of the edges of the iron. If there's excessive leakage, use less batter for the next waffle.
Cook until the waffle iron's indicator light shows that cooking is complete, or until no more steam comes out. The finished waffle should be golden brown and crispy.
Lift the waffle out of the iron with a pair of tongs and either serve right away or transfer it to the oven to keep warm
